data.title: Not Worth the Time/Terrible Event Venue
data.text: The only nice thing I can say is that the building itself is lovely.  I have been here for two exhibits and a wedding.  All three visits were made awful by the staff and volunteers.  Their event coordinator has to be one of the rudest people I've ever encountered.

data.title: A Community Museum
data.text:
Besides an interesting art museum they also offer children's art classes. The local school district has a large show of student art there each year that is very impressive.
The shows   change out on a regular basis usually spotlighting individual artists. Free to the public. Check for current shows and hours. Located in downtown Arlington.

data.title: Piece of History in the Heart of TX
data.text: Love  this museum; its always packed with special history and notable events. Arlington Tx has an abundant of history ...a town with a few previous names, heck this town was once noted for its healing Springs, which was located in the middle of downtown.

data.title: Great place for an event/wedding
data.text: The ambiance is beautiful, and the roof top offers spectacular views.  Even more, you'll love the price!  I do love planning events here.

data.title: Great Arlington Gem
data.text: Really cool Vivian Maier exhibit.  I've been wanting to see this before it ended.  I barely made it and ended up having to bring my 4 year old.  It all turned out great! The musuem was is small but nice.  The staff was kind. The exhibit was really cool.  I wish I had longer to linger, but with a toddler in tow it all went very quick quick. I'll be back!

data.title: Impressed
data.text: Had to see the Vivian Maier exhibit while it was here.  Museum staff was amazing.  Went out of their way to make sure we were well informed and took pictures of us.  Enjoyable experience.

data.title: Vivian Maier - Lost and Found Exhibit
data.text: Having just watched the documentary on Netflix my children and I were very excited to go see her work. It's a small museum with limited parking spaces out front. When you walk in there is a small table to pay, $8 for adults free for children under 12. It's rather informal, the first level had lots of tables set up on the floor and there were probably 25 photographs framed on the first floor. I love her work, quite amazing for her time period. You could tell she had a fantastic eye for photography. You can access the upstairs by stairs or elevator. Near the elevator is a small gift shop, counter really, where they sell t- shirts and other small items. Upstairs there are three small sections where each group of art was organized. The lighting definitely needs to be looked at better to highlight the works of art. We spent about 30 minutes here. I really wish they could receive an amazing grant or donation to bring this museum to the next level. For a city the size of Arlington this really should be a bit more exciting and up to date.

data.title: Vivian Maier Photography Exhibit
data.text: The museum was very fortunate to be able display some very beautiful prints from Vivian Maier and it is very worthwhile if you love good, unpretentious photography.

data.title: Hosts excellent works but needs improvement
data.text: This is a small 2-story museum which appears to host one visiting exhibit at a time. I visited to see the Vivian Maier exhibit which is running here until late August. The setup is a bit informal; there is a table at the entrance and a small museum store in an open area in a far corner of the room--which were fine. However, a few of the works were displayed in a slightly darkened area because the tiny ceiling spotlights pointing to them were 'out.'  Additionally, there was no 'story-telling' signage or short film putting the work in context. I really enjoyed Maier's photography, but there's an interesting story about her and how her work was discovered--which is running as a documentary on Netflix right now--and some of that story whether provided as text on the walls or as a few video snippets would've made the exhibit much more interesting to visitors unfamiliar with her work.

data.title: Great exhibits in a small museum
data.text: The Dallas/Ft. Worth area is known for its world-class museums, such as the Kimbell, Amon Carter, Ft. Worth Modern and Dallas Museum of Art, among others. If you are in the area, don't miss these. But Arlington has its own downtown museum, located minutes from AT&T Stadium, Globe Life Park and Six Flags Over Texas. The Arlington Museum of Art features ever-changing traveling exhibits of works that span history and geography. It is easy to get to and its small size makes for a great way to spend an hour or two. If you are in Arlington, add this gem to your itinerary.

data.title: Small but cute museum
data.text: My friend and I went because we got a Groupon for it. It was a pretty small museum but it had some interesting pieces. We only spent about 30 minutes there and saw/discusses everything. The staff was very friendly.

data.title: Enjoyable exhibit when I went
data.text: The museum is small and doesn't have a permanent exhibit. I went to see the exhibit on Toulouse Lautrec and other contemporary French painters. I thoroughly enjoed it. The all-volunteer staff were very friendly and knowledgeable of the exhibit.

data.title: Good Photography class
data.text: went on a saturday for a photography class and then hung out and checked out some of the art. nice displays, very well done.

data.title: Toulouse-Lautrec exhibit Outstanding
data.text: Well staged, wide range, a pleasure to view in a smaller museum,film was an added extra.  Walking up the curved stairs while viewing was a little disconcerting.

data.title: LowB rated
data.text:
This museum leaves a LOT to be desired. I have a membership and attend all events but always am disappointed.  They try to make the exhibit sound good but when you get there, it is so 'not worth it'.  The Christmas Tree exhibit was so trashy. The trees were 'kind of' decorated with old, terribly used ornaments. Some had only a few ornaments as if it was an after thought.  Recently we went for the opening of an exhibit and they were having a "reception".  They had very limited snacks and drinks.  The table with the popcorn and snack crackers had no plates, just napkins, although we saw a few people filling up bowls.  We asked a lady where the plates or bowls were and she told us "the bowls are only for the museum employees".  We asked what are we suppose to put the food on?  She said 'in our hand or on a napkin'.  So we know what they think of the paying guests!  
The whole place is a disappointment everytime I go so beware, it is not a top notch museum.
Just a very low B rated place.  Too bad because I am always hoping for better.

data.title: Neat little museum
data.text: Recently visited the Toulouse-Lautrec exhibit with friends. It was a neat exhibit and a nice way to spend a couple hours out of the sun. The museum is reasonably priced as well as has discounts for students, librarians and military. The museum is 2 floors with a movie/film area on the first floor. There is a small gift shop counter as well. The museum is spacious and the staff is friendly.

data.title: Surprisingly good, but staff don't know how good.
data.text:
Saw a poster for a traveling exhibition here, and stopped in about 2 hours before closing.  It was a very nice exhibit, but was really surprised that the staff did not quite realize how nice.  Yes, it is a city museum in a suburb right between Dallas and Ft. Worth.  Yes, either of those towns easily dwarf Arlington in terms of what they can offer.  But this had the vibe not of a smaller gallery, but of a small town museum that was desperately trying to be noticed.

We saw a show of work from the French post-Impressionists.  It was quite nicely done, and contained lots of work that we found really first rate.  But when asking about places for dinner, we were not really impressed by the chains that the staff recommended. Especially when we found out that there is a wonderful French cafe just a few blocks away that has food and wine that really complemented the show.  Clearly the place is just getting it's feet under it.  Yes, a long way to improve, but Arlington is coming up quickly.

data.title: Community Venue and Halloween stop for the little ones.
data.text: So my art was displayed here as a child in the AISD, and I took art classes here in the basement. It's a great community venue. I also brought my daughter for Halloween. She had so much fun! it was the highlight of our trick or treating.

data.title: Small venue, Huge showing
data.text: Arlington isn't a world renowned metropolis. There's no MoMA, but that doesn't matter. I saw an AMAZING Ansel Adams exhibit, here. A wonderful installation, and a great docu. Everything I've seen here, has been delightfully surprising. This is also a great wedding/reception venue

data.title: It's got a long way to go
data.text: I'm not sure what this place is trying to be. It has a rather strange layout with an institutional feel upon entry. The good thing; is a room upstairs for local art shows including photography.
